central_thesis: The Secret Grimoire of Turiel presents a complete system of Ceremonial Magic, rooted in Kabbalistic and grimoire traditions, for the invocation and conjuration of planetary spirits and intelligences (including Olympic Spirits and their messengers like Turiel), enabling the practitioner to gain knowledge, assistance, and influence over various worldly and spiritual affairs through divine authority and ritual precision.

structure_content.summary: Describes the book's provenance, detailing its origin as a 1518 Latin manuscript, an English copy acquired in 1927, and its subsequent rewriting by Marius Malchus in 1954. It asserts the work constitutes a complete system of Ceremonial Magic, emphasizing its unique survival and appeal to occult students.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part I: Preparations, Consecrations, and Implements
structure_content.summary: Outlines the essential prerequisites for the operator, including a seven-day period of seclusion, fasting, and prayer, culminating in ritual purification. It details the precise methods for drawing a nine-foot magical circle, crafting pentacles, and consecrating all necessary magical tools such as the girdle, light (candles), sword, and vestments, ensuring their divine efficacy.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part I: Invocations for the Days of the Week
structure_content.summary: Provides specific invocations and associated sigils/pentacles for each day of the week, linking them to their corresponding planetary influences and divine names. These invocations are designed to establish contact with Heavenly Spirits aligned with the respective planetary energies, preparing the magical atmosphere for deeper operations.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part I: Characters and Perfumes of the Lords of the Seven Planets
structure_content.summary: Presents the unique sigils ('Characters') and elaborate perfume recipes for each of the seven Olympic Spirits (Aratron for Saturn, Phaleg for Mars, Phul for Moon, Bethor for Jupiter, Ophiel for Mercury, Hagith for Venus, Och for Sun). An important editorial footnote addresses the traditional use of blood in perfume recipes, suggesting egg white as a contemporary, ethically sound, and energetically equivalent substitute.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part II: Containing Invocations, Conjurions, and Exorcisms of the Band of Spirits
structure_content.summary: Details the main operative sequence for conjuring spirits. It begins with an oration for donning vestments, followed by the central 'Lamen' sigil. Extensive prayers and powerful invocations employ a multitude of divine names (e.g., Adonay, Tetragrammaton, Sabaoth) to command and bind planetary spirits, particularly focusing on the Jupiterian spirits and their messenger, Turiel. The section culminates in the exact dialogue for interrogating the evoked spirit, granting a license to depart, and formalizing a 'Bond of Spirits' to ensure future compliance, and provides the unique sigil for Turiel.

structure_content.chapter_title: Now Follow The Rites of Magick From The Various Ancient Grimoires
structure_content.summary: Expands on the nature and powers of the seven Olympic Spirits, detailing their specific domains and abilities (e.g., Aratron's power over petrification, Bethor's ability to bestow treasures). It provides a general prayer template for invoking any Olympic Spirit and includes comprehensive tables of planetary hours for both day and night, crucial for timing magical operations to align with specific planetary influences.

key_concepts.definition: The four-letter divine name, YHWH, which is a central power source in the Grimoire, inscribed on many talismans and invoked in numerous conjurations to assert divine authority over spirits.
A system of magic structured around the seven classical planets, each associated with specific days, hours, spirits, divine names, and virtues, dictating the timing and nature of evocations.

A specific hierarchy of planetary rulers—Aratron (Saturn), Bethor (Jupiter), Phaleg (Mars), Och (Sun), Hagith (Venus), Ophiel (Mercury), Phul (Moon)—each possessing distinct powers and domains, invoked for various magical effects.
A nine-foot diameter circumscription drawn on the ground, serving as the consecrated operational space for the magician, providing protection and a focal point for the ritual.

Talismanic diagrams, often circular, inscribed with Hebrew divine names, spirit characters, and magical symbols, used as a focal point for invocation and as a symbolic representation of the magician's authority or the spirit's essence.
The ritual act of purifying and charging magical tools, the workspace, and the operator, imbuing them with divine virtue and power to ensure the efficacy and safety of the magical operation.

Specific incense mixtures composed of herbs, animal products (historically), and other substances corresponding to a particular planet and its spirits, used to create an appropriate energetic environment for evocation. The text notes a shift away from blood to substitutes like egg white.
A unique symbolic representation or 'mark' of a specific spirit or planetary intelligence, used in ritual to call forth and identify the entity, and often inscribed on talismans.

A formal oath or covenant sworn by the evoked spirit (e.g., Turiel) to the magician, promising appearance, truthfulness, and assistance for the duration of the magician's life, in exchange for the magician's adherence to sacred vows.

practical_system.description: The system described is a comprehensive framework for ceremonial planetary magic, focused on the evocation of spirits for various purposes. It mandates a stringent preparatory phase for the operator, including seven days of physical and spiritual purification. Key to the operation is the precise timing of rituals according to planetary hours, the construction and consecration of specific magical tools and talismans (pentacles/lamens), and the use of corresponding planetary perfumes. The core process involves invoking divine names to establish authority, conjuring the desired planetary spirit (e.g., Turiel, a Messenger of Jupiter), and engaging in a structured dialogue to extract information or commands, culminating in a binding oath and formal dismissal.
tools: Pentacles and Lamens (general and specific daily/planetary sigils)
Planetary Perfumes (specific compositions for each planet)
Hazel Wand (both forked and straight versions)
rituals: Seven-day period of seclusion, fasting, and prayer for operator purification.
Ritual drawing of a nine-foot magical circle for protection and ritual space.
Creation and consecration of specific planetary pentacles and lamens.
Consecration of all magical implements: girdle, light (candles), sword, and vestments.
Daily invocations tailored to the specific planetary energies of the day.
Specific conjurations of planetary spirits (e.g., Sachiel, Castiel, Asasiel, and Turiel for Jupiter) using extensive lists of divine names.
Structured interrogation of the evoked spirit to gain knowledge or confirm requests.
Formal 'License to Depart' ritual for the safe dismissal of the spirit.
Negotiation and confirmation of a 'Bond of Spirits' as an agreement for future assistance.

relevant_quotes.text: It has much to commend it. Though small in volume it is a complete system of Ceremonial Magic.

Retire thyself Seven Days free from all company and fast and pray from sunset to sunrise. Rise every morning at Seven of the clock, and the three days previous to the Work fast upon bread and water and humble thyself before Almighty God. Watch and pray all night before the Work.

O Great God Who art the God of strength and fortitude and greatly to be feared, bless O Lord, this Instrument that it may be a terror unto the Enemy, and therewith I may fight with and over-come all phantasms and oppositions of the Enemy, through the influence and help of Thy most Holy Mighty Name, On, St. Agla, and in the Cross of Jesus Christ our only Lord. Amen.

On this and subsequent occasions when the use of blood or parts of animals is specified we have retained the wording of the original MS. for the sake of authenticity. We would, however, remark that in the opinion of experienced occultists the use of blood is neither desirable nor essential, being apt to have a bad effect upon the operator. It is suggested that the white of a new-laid egg would prove an effective substitute, having a similar life potential, and being equally suitable as a cohesive medium.

I, Turiel, Messenger of the Spirits of Jupiter, appointed there-unto by the Creator of all things visible and invisible, do swear and promise, and plighting faith and troth unto thee in the presence, by, and before the Great Lord of Heaven… thus do I swear now, and promise unto thee that I will hasten unto thee, and appear clearly unto thee at all times and places, and in all hours, days, and minutes, from this time forward until thy life's end…

critical_analysis.relevance: The Secret Grimoire of Turiel is highly relevant as a practical manual within the Solomonic and broader grimoire tradition, demonstrating a Christianized Kabbalistic approach to spirit evocation. It provides a structured, step-by-step system for engaging with planetary intelligences, emphasizing preparation, divine authority, and the utility of spirits. Its inclusion of editorial notes on controversial practices like blood sacrifice reflects an adaptation to modern occult ethics while preserving historical text, bridging ancient practice with contemporary concerns.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience includes advanced practitioners of ceremonial magic, students of Western Esotericism and Qabalah, historians of occultism interested in grimoire traditions, and individuals seeking detailed, operative instructions for planetary spirit evocation. It particularly appeals to those who appreciate a hierarchical, divinely sanctioned approach to magical work.
